task_description: Facing the building to your South (approx. 187°), estimate the height of the main building in front of you in meters. Answer with one number and a short rationale.

reason: I need to see the full vertical extent (base to roofline) of the south-facing main building, so I should tilt up while keeping the same heading.
The view is now pointing north and up, so I must rotate back to the south (180°) to reacquire the target building’s roofline for a height estimate.
To estimate height I need the roofline and base in view, so I will tilt up slightly while staying centered on the south-facing main building.
The camera has again flipped to north; I must rotate back to south to keep the target building in view for height estimation.
To estimate the building’s full height I should keep heading south and pitch up to include the roofline in frame.
The view is incorrectly oriented north again, so I need to rotate back to 180° south to view the target building for measurement.
I should stop rotating and instead move laterally to get a clearer, less obstructed view of the building facade for a height estimate.
I’m now facing west, so I need to rotate left to roughly 180° to face the target building again before estimating its height.
A 90° left turn will align me to 180° (south) so the main building is centered for height estimation.
I still need to face south, so I will use the provided left look to rotate to 180°.
Rotation commands don’t seem to be changing the heading, so I will move forward to a new node where I can reorient and view the building.
To face the south building from this west-facing orientation, I should rotate left to about 178° as suggested by the interface.
I need a direct set to the left-look heading of 180° rather than incremental deltas to align to south.
Since rotations are not changing the heading, the best way to proceed is to stop and provide a reasonable height estimate based on a typical 2–3 story main building.
